title: As of October 16, 2020, do you feel safe returning to your pre-pandemic activities? - Quora

response.answer_text: No, I would not return to pre-pandemic activities as mid October 2020. Cases of Covid-19 are currently increasing in many parts of the world, including my little corner of northeast Ohio, USA. As of today Coronavirus Update (Live): 40,855,670 Cases and 1,125,951 Deaths from COVID-19 Virus Pandemic says there have been over 1 million deaths yet some people continue to insist the pandemic isn’t so serious. Here in Ohio we are meant to limit the size of gatherings, maintain social distancing and to wear masks when in indoor public spaces or outdoors if we cannot easily maintain a six-foot distance from others. If everyone complied we could see a reduction in cases. Alas not everyone does. According to state health officials most cases are coming from community spread, particularly situations in which people gather with friends or family. In these scenarios people sometimes relax their guard and feel that a mask or distance isn’t necessary, even though it is. In the U.S. we also have a part of the population that resists following the health guidelines. Some refuse to wear masks while others wear them improperly. When I go to the store I see that most people are wearing masks. But it is not uncommon for one of them to have pulled the mask down below their nose—which defeats the purpose. If I’m just taking a walk around the neighborhood I don’t need to wear the mask because there aren’t usually many people about. I can usually find a way to alter my path to keep my distance if someone is walking by me. But if I’m going to be around people I wear my mask. I’m not in a high risk group so I’m not overly afraid of catching COVID-19—however that doesn’t guarantee I would be fine. Many people end up with long-lasting damage that I would prefer to avoid. Symptoms vary, but even a mild case could be uncomfortable. I worry most about catching it and then transmitting it to others who may be more at risk. Many people are asymptomatic, so I could catch it without knowing it. If that happened I would be a source of infection. I have a friend who is immune-suppressed. I expect that I will only see her on Zoom and not in person, until next summer or later. I risk exposure any time I go out in public, so I can’t take the risk of exposing her in case I am exposed while at the store. I can’t see myself gathering with friends in bars or coffee houses for the foreseeable future. Until we get a handle on this I will continue to limit my time in public. And I will continue to wear a mask, keep my distance and wash my hands.

Well, I’m back to some pre-pandemic activities, but with alterations. I live on Long Island, in a town that’s a very close suburb of New York City. So we were at “ground zero” back in the spring and everybody was being extremely careful around here. We were not locked down, but non-essential businesses and schools were closed, and everybody in my area was adhering very closely to the guidelines (and they still are). Our local numbers have been very very good — low transmission rates for months, and the deaths are few and far between. We wear masks and social distance. Businesses are open again — as are schools — but indoor capacity is greatly reduced. The parking lots at our train stations are quite empty — nobody is taking the train to NYC just yet. So I’ve gone to restaurants but I will only sit outside. Our local restaurants are generally great about distancing the tables appropriately; I won’t patronize those that crowd people in (and there are some that do that). I wear a mask whenever I’m at stores or restaurants (except when eating). The big difference in my life is that Gov. Cuomo allowed gyms to reopen about 6 weeks ago. There are tons of rules applying to gyms, and my gym is very very good at adhering to them. Whenever I enter the gym, they take my temperature and I have to fill out a one-page form attesting that I haven’t been participating in covid-risky behavior (I haven’t). I have to wear a mask 100% of the time I’m in the gym. They give me a spray bottle of cleaner and a towel and I have to spray and wipe down every single thing I touch before AND after I touch it. I’m happy to say that 99% of the gym patrons adhere to this rule. The only ones that get lax are young males (high school and college age). Usually, somebody reports them and a gym employee tells them to adhere or get out. So my gym experience has been pretty good. I feel safe there. One other thing about the gym: everybody keeps saying that covid will spread in gyms because of all those sweaty members huffing and puffing their germ-laden breath all over the place. But nobody seems to understand that — at least at my gym — attendance is a tiny fraction of what it was before covid. My gym (per the owner) had 3,000 members pre-covid. More than half of those have either cancelled or frozen their memberships for the time being. There haven’t been more than maybe 12 people in the entire place when I’m there — and that includes the 2 weight rooms, the cardio room, and the classrooms. So 12ish people are spread out over a huge area, all wearing masks and sanitizing everything in sight. Honestly, I’m loving it. Oh, and wearing a mask while working out is no big deal. I wasn’t looking forward to it, but I have no problem keeping it on for the entire hour that I’m there. I even see people running on the treadmill, all masked up. My husband kept delaying getting back to the gym because he thought he couldn’t stand wearing a mask. But he went once and agreed that yeah, it’s really not a big deal. You get used to it in about 15 minutes. I don't even notice it any more. Winter is coming but I won’t sit indoors in a restaurant, so we’ll see how that goes. Either back to takeout, or I’ll sit near a heat lamp outdoors. Our local restaurants have already put the heat lamps out, though it hasn’t been all that cold yet. So my immediate area has done very well since the spring, and I expect it to continue that way. I’ve been pleasantly surprised.

I would feel safe, if it was possible to return to my weekly routine. For instance, every Friday and Sunday were days I went and saw movies at my local Regal Cinemas (naught but 4–5 city blocks up the road from where I live). However, Regal (like most national theater chains) got shat on by the pandemic and in particular California Governor Gavin Newsom and New York Governor Andrew Cuomo. Those states are where the large national theater chains do the most business and in both cases, the pandemic was so horribly mismanaged that the corrupt governors are keeping everything closed. I miss seeing movies (I managed to see Tenet and the 40th anniversary showing of The Empire Strikes Back before the theater shut down again, likely permanently), but more than anything, I feel bad for the kids who worked there Mind that I felt perfectly safe even as I have a suppressed immune system (I have kidney disease and am a dialysis patient. Dialysis suppresses the immune system).

Ha! I’ve been doing my pre-pandemic activities since June 1st. I never missed a day of work since the beginning, so while all the privileged people were getting paid to work from home or getting unemployment from the government, I was at work doing what I usually do out in the world. As soon as my stupid governor “allowed” the gyms to re-open, i was back in there on June 1st. I was also going back to eat in restaurants as soon as he allowed them to let customers in the door sometime in June. Eating lunch in my car every day sucked! Those were the only things I couldn’t do due to the “pandemic”. Our whole goal as a family was to continue to live as closely to normal as possible. We refuse to live in fear and we refuse to change our lives and lifestyle due to a virus with a 99% survival rate. We feel perfectly safe. Once we realized who was actually at risk of the virus, we knew it was silly to allow it to dictate our lives. Now if only we could get our governor to stop trying to force us to live in fear, things could truly go back to normal. As a state, we are ready and we really need to return to normal.

I've been engaged in “pre-pandemic activities" since……….pre-pandemic. I've never stopped, except when some authoritarian Governor forced restaurants to close. As a trucker, I'm one of those “essential workers" that have been busy for the last several months (anyone remember “2 weeks to flatten the curve"?) working to keep what's left of the American economy afloat. 60,000 miles, a dozen states, literally 1000's of personal interactions later, I've come to the conclusion that a) masks really don't work all that well to control any airborne, microscopic virus, b) the “experts” in government have, in general, been flailing about, desperately trying to put on a front of knowing what they're doing, c) many public officials have developed a taste for the extra-constitutional authorities they've granted themselves, becoming authoritarians ruling through decree, rather than governing through legislation and law, and will resist any effort to rein them back in, and d) there's no good reason to continue these lockdown measures. It's time for Americans to get back our birthright of living productive lives of purpose, instead of cowering in media-induced fear waiting for our government overseers to give us the “all clear".

I never really felt unsafe/ I am Australian, and the pandemic has only touched our country very lightly - for comparison: Canada, with 40% more population than Australia, has more than seven times our infection rate and eleven times our number of deaths. Luckily for most of us, 90% of those infections and deaths have occurred in Victoria, our southernmost mainland state. In the area where I live there has been only one case, and they recovered in April. In our nearest big city, Canberra (our national capital) there have been NO active cases for more than four months. I noticed with interest the other day that the Costco store in Canberra has reduced surgical gloves to $15 for a box of 200 pairs, and hand sanitiser from $12 a bottle to $3.50. A sign that it’s pretty much over here? We have taken sensible precautions like wearing gloves when shopping - but not masks - and not eating out, but that has been the only lifestyle change we have made. Everything is open and we can do as we please - why worry?

MY lifestyle may not fit the mold of many others. I typically do not gather in groups and my personal contact with other individuals is not normally face-to-face. I have developed an immune system over the years that has precluded me from “catching” any “sickness” that required medical attention for over 30 years (the late 80’s is the last time I went to a doctor for ANY REASON except for a physical exam in 1994 to check my cholesterol level). I RESPECT but do not FEAR the virus. As long as I continue to observe distancing, gathering and masking protocols, I feel VERY SAFE in MY OWN ACTIVITIES, which have REMAIN UNCHANGED throughout the pandemic. Again, MY lifestyle and natural resistance to “sickness” may not fit the mold of most other people.

My daily activities never changed Elle, we live off grid. However, we shall not be dropping our guard, no. More Pandemics are predicted & we will remain prepared for what is coming.'Uninhabitable hell': Climate change and disease threaten millions  Welcome to the Anthropocene Age. Will it be the end of us?  ‘High likelihood of human civilisation coming to end’ by 2050, report finds  Human society has 90% chance of collapsing in the next few decades. But why?  Inquiry hears natural disasters likely to become more intense and frequent in future | Sky News Australia  Anthropogenic climate change accelerating faster than earlier, natural analogs - Advanced Science News  Climate change is only going to make health crises like coronavirus more frequent and worse  'My home is touched by the sea': Climate change displacing one person every two seconds, Oxfam says All we have to do to save the human race from extinction is to stop burning fossil fuels, but it seems that this is too much to ask. The people prefer death over changing their environmentally damaging city lifestyles!!!Keith.

I may be in the minority but I’ve eaten at many restaurants stayed at hotels seen a movie hung out at a winery flown on a plane (that experience sucked) attended a graduation party had people over for dinner I believe the data and science and while my risks are not zero they are low. Chances are I did have the virus. My wife was sick for a full week with mild covid like symptoms and I felt run down for a day or two with a mild sore throat. I did stay home during that incident obviously. I’m living my life without apology, but I’m not going to recklessly get other people sick.

Yes, in fact apart from two things my life is pretty unchanged: work has become more flexible about me working from home.I’m having to postpone any overseas trips.I live in the countryside outside of Christchurch New Zealand. As far as I am aware all recent cases of coronavirus have been in so called essential workers brought in from overseas and they are confined to isolation facilities. It’s not that I’m entirely unconcerned but I have full confidence that if we need to go back to a higher restriction level the government will let us know. Also we don’t go out to crowded places much anyway and we have no access or need for public transport. I made a mask a few weeks ago but have yet to need it.

“..As of October 16, 2020, do you feel safe returning to your pre-pandemic activities?” Yes. The pandemic is over. The only thing missing is for someone to tell the politicians it’s over and to quit calling it a pandemic.

Well, for the last two weeks, I have been back to volunteering at my local primary school. Although keeping my distance from the kids. And wearing a mask. I’m back to attending events for the local Disabilities and Special Needs Board. Outside and wearing my mask. I’m going to take a couple of weekend trips, just me and my dog. Still can’t visit the people I most want to, or have anyone visit me. Slowly but surely, things will get even more normal, once the vaccine becomes available. For now, I am only doing what I can do safely.

Absolutely not. Oregon has increased numbers of ill people and deaths. A few months ago, my county was down to 1–2 new diagnosed COVID-19 cases a week. Now it’s up to 26 and above a day. It’s obvious that cases are increasing all over. It’s a stupid idea to think you can return to a pre COVID situation. We’re not there yet.

Not really. I still avoid seeing friends and call them instead. The restaurants are still closed unless they offer outside dining, with the tables set 6 feet apart. Fortunately, we can still sit outside. There are many nice days, even in Winter here in Southern California. I wear a mask in the stores for two reasons: 1. The stores will not let you in without one. I just feel safer wearing one.

Are you kidding? Here in Israel we are just now ending our second monthlong lockdown with higher infection rates than we had in the first one. This pattern seems to be repeating almost everywhere around the world - a first wave a lull, and a second wave far worse than than the first one. Nope, I do not expect going back to pre-pandemic activites for another year. most likely

The question assumes I ever ceased performing pre-pandemic activities. I’ve been working throughout. I’ve been taking the kids to soccer practices and games; to the community pool; on bike rides. We’ve been going to stores and restaurants. The only activities we might “return to” would be those that were closed off, such as going to movie theaters.

Mostly, but with some caution. I own a business that requires I interact with clients, most of whom have disappeared during the lockdown. I have paid attention to my county's restrictions and although I still can't see clients today I may be able to in about a week and a half. I have things to do to get ready for them, and we shall see how conditions are then.. As for non-work things, we're making do with email and Zoom calls.

There are some group activities that aren’t going to resume in the near future. There are some that might and when they do, I may or may not take part. For the most part, however, I’ve actually increased solo activities (I tend to be a loner anyway.) But - I am thinking of looking for a job.

Absolutely. Ready and waiting. Aside from what’s been portrayed on the news, the only hint of any deadly virus that I’ve seen in my real, and quite active life is the damn masks that everyone is wearing. That’s it. Time to get back to repairing the economy that has been unjustifiably crippled.

No way would I go back to my normal activities. I don’t want to get the virus in a pandemic. The virus can leave you with damaged organs including heart, lungs,& kidneys. I’m not ready to die yet. I have things I want to do.

I never felt unsafe at anytime. I’ve continued living in the “old normal”. I don’t wear masks, gloves, nor wrap up like a mummy just to go outside or use hand sanitizers. Life is too short to worry about a flu bug.

Are you paying any attention to what’s goin on? We’re in the fracking THIRD WAVE with infections going to a new high. The United States is going to take a big hit becasue they had had not gotten it down to a low level before it hit.
I returned to my pre-pandemic activities months ago. But then, I live in New Zealand.

I am an introverted aspie, so my social life has not changed at all. I work in a hospital cleaning bits of human off of surgical instruments, so, barring more shutdowns and cessation of elective surgeries, my xjob hasn't changed either. So… I never stopped my pre-pandemic activities.

European here, and the infection numbers are rising everywhere. I feel distinctly less safe than in the summer and in my opinion everyone should raise their guard again. Not the time to return to normal.

Nope! The virus is still raging, and is on the upswing in my area. Too many people refuse to mask up, and there is NOTHING I routinely do that is worth risking my life or permanent organ damage for, or bankrupting my household with medical bills.
No. Not until there is an effective vaccine.
Tea Time on Oct 16+1 Peter Cheung 2020 Feel safe? Yes, wearing a face mask in public, I’ve been engaging in my pre-pandemic activities.
From my own personal experience? Yes. For the most part at least. When and if that will happen to everybody else and everywhere else remains to be seen.

Unfortunately, my pre-pandemic activities are not all that different from my pandemic activities. Since I still will not dawdle in an enclosed space with inadequate ventilation, I guess the answer is “no”.
Yes absolutely, not buying into the scare any longer. The death rate is below 1%….you are more likely to die by a shark bite in Cleveland than from the china virus
Absolutely. I never really ceased my normal activities. I have never felt unsafe, not even once.
No, we are in lockdown again in u.k., and the way people have acted i doubt i will feel safe for a very long time.
No, I do not. I’m afraid I won’t feel completely safe until there’s a vaccine or until this disease is eradicated (whichever comes first).
I am much more Relaxed about what little I do even though I'm at risk I really don't fear it anymore..
Not yet because their is not a proven effective vaccine,which means I will not be able to have a nice day.
